Conrad's Jerry Quigg and Bob Satterfield placed second and third behind Salesianum's Vic Zwolak to lead Conrad to the team title.

Twenty-seven years later, Delaware hosted its first girls cross-country state championship. Caesar Rodney senior Shelley Smith, who had already established herself as one of Delaware's best in fall invitationals and on the track, won the Killens Pond 5k in a time that would have slotted third among all runners at the most recent state meet at Killens four decades later. Padua won the first of its 24 team titles.

Since then, thousands of Delawareans have tested themselves in cross country and track and field. We have attempted to craft a list of the 75 greatest distance runners — those who set records, won championships and led the state's best teams.

search_result.title: In effort to improve sports teams, University of Delaware pays more ...
search_result.text:
Four years after new President Dennis Assanis and athletic director Chrissi Rawak pledged to make University of Delaware sports teams bigger winners, UD’s financial investment in athletics is among the national front-runners while Blue Hen teams often remain Colonial Athletic Association also-rans.

Delaware’s expenditures on athletics are second-highest among schools in the NCAA Division I Football Championship Subdivision, data analysis reveals.

Only conference rival James Madison spends more, according to the Knight Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics’ financial information database.

James Madison has won a league-high 17 conference championships the last four years, 10 more than Delaware.

Furthermore, when looking at all NCAA Division I schools, including those in the highest level, the Football Bowl Subdivision, Delaware ranks 70th nationally in operating expenses and fourth in terms of how much of its athletic support is drawn from institutional/government resources. That’s among 230 public schools in statistics compiled by USA Today.

Little Delaware isn’t such a lightweight, apparently, when it comes to splurging on sports in a bid to become more relevant in its conference and even nationally. Delaware allocates a greater amount of university-derived money toward athletics than most schools.

Blue Hens teams did begin to turn the corner in 2019-20, logging a 147-99-4 record before the coronavirus pandemic forced a premature end to winter and spring athletics in March.

CLASSES TO RESUME: UD announces fall semester plans, changes

The $38.23 million in athletic funding that came directly from the institution in 2017-18, the most recent school year for which information is available, was considerably more than any of Delaware’s FCS counterparts, according to the Knight Commission.

Next, were conference football rivals Rhode Island ($20.48 million) and Stony Brook ($17.22 million).

“They stand out because there was an investment,” Rawak said of those financial figures. "I don't think there is anything wrong with that, especially if we are producing."

But is that investment too significant?

Only one FBS athletic program received more in government/institutional support – the United States Air Force Academy ($39.8 million), according to the Knight Commission's 2017-18 data.

The subject came up last fall at a UD board of trustees’ committee on student life and athletics summit. Meeting minutes describe “a robust discussion” on the topic of spending “finite” resources on athletics and concerns about “the potential return” on the investment.

It was initiated by Matt Robinson, head of the UD sport management program who had been the interim athletic director in the first half of 2016 before Rawak’s hiring. Robinson had raised concerns about the university’s considerable subsidization of athletics with Rawak during the meeting.

While acknowledging the discussion took place, Robinson, who is also UD Faculty Senate president, preferred not to comment further on the topic when recently asked by Delaware Online/The News Journal.

Assanis had responded to Robinson’s concerns by expressing that he and other university presidents share the wish “to elevate their institutions through success in athletics,” meeting minutes reported.

Surely, sports accomplishments are attention-getters that can fuel enrollment and fund-raising, though UD’s strong academic reputation and picturesque campus have long been powerful lures in their own right.

Rawak described athletics as “a window to the broader public” that could “drive the success of the entire university,” according to board of trustees meeting minutes.

But college athletics is also a costly venture.

Division I schools away from the Power Five bloc, which includes the Big Ten, Big 12, ACC, SEC and Pac-12 with their lucrative TV packages and wealthy donors, have a particularly difficult time finding outside funding sources.

ALL IN: CAA announces all teams will qualify for postseason tournaments

The coronavirus crisis has cast additional light on those high costs and athletic spending often viewed as frivolous, such as coaches’ salaries, staffing, scheduling and travel, especially from far-flung conference alignment. It has forced many to rethink their approaches and ensure spending is efficient and frugal.

In April, UD announced the pandemic had left it with a $65 million overall budget shortfall because of the switch to online learning after students were sent home and all university events were canceled in mid-March.

Athletic financial losses were not severe but certainly impactful, Rawak suggested. The only cuts announced so far affecting athletics have been some part-time positions. Staff development, travel and scheduling are areas where budgets will be trimmed, Rawak said.

The basketball teams staying overnight at hotels before games at nearby Drexel and Towson and the football team sleeping in a hotel the night before home games are potential cost-cutting targets. This fall, the soccer, volleyball and field hockey teams are playing fewer games that involve significantly less travel.

"We're in a different time now," Rawak said of COVID-19's impact on college athletics and the need to adjust.

A slew of Division I schools have recently dropped sports: Old Dominion (wrestling); Cincinnati (men’s soccer); Furman (baseball and men’s lacrosse); Central Michigan (men’s track and field); Akron (men’s cross country, men’s golf, women’s tennis); East Carolina (men’s and women’s tennis, men’s and women’s swimming); Florida International (men’s indoor track); Appalachian State (men’s soccer, men’s indoor and outdoor track and men’s tennis); Wright State (men’s and women’s tennis and softball); Connecticut (men's cross country, swimming and tennis and women's rowing); and Brown (11 sports). Before those cuts, Brown's 38 teams were more than any school nationally except Harvard and Stanford.

Except for FCS-level Furman and Brown and non-football playing Wright State, all are FBS schools in Group of Five conferences. Commissioners from that collection of leagues, which do not reap the economic windfall of Power Five schools, recently requested a reduction in the NCAA requirement that they field a minimum of 16 teams. The NCAA Division I Council denied it.

Delaware, which fields 21 athletic teams, had $44.32 million in athletic funding and expenses in the most recent 2017-18 fiscal review, according to the Knight Commission, including that $38.23 million in university backing. The $44.32 million was the figure that ranked 70th nationally in USA Today’s accounting.

By contrast, 34 football-playing schools from the FBS Mid-American Conference, Conference USA and Sun Belt Conference – all in that Group of Five – had lower operating expenses on athletics than Delaware, including sport-killers Central Michigan, Akron, FIU and Appalachian State.

FBS schools may award 85 football scholarships compared with 63 for FCS schools such as Delaware, a significant additional expense.

Rawak, however, dismissed the Knight Commission math, claiming it gives a false impression that, she said, makes Delaware stand out more than it should in relation to its Division I peers.

For example, she said, sports medicine operates out of the Carpenter Center and is counted as part of the funding supporting athletics but is actually overseen by UD Student Health.

She also said some schools do not count the significant cost of athletic facility groundskeeping, as Delaware does, in figures given to the Knight Commission.

“How everybody counts money is very different,” she said, including scholarships in those accounting variances. “It creates more questions.”

The Knight Commission, founded in 1989, is a panel of experts in education and athletics that aims to ensure college sports function within the academic framework of the institutions. The Collegiate Athletics Financial Information Database aims to improve the accountability of public Division I institutions by making their spending and earning more transparent.

DREAM COMES TRUE: UD pitcher Sullivan signs with Phillies

“I would guarantee you there are a lot of universities that are supported the way we are but they don’t count it so it’s not an accurate interpretation,” Rawak said, adding that includes fellow Colonial Athletic Association members.

In an email response to questions, Amy Perko, the Knight Commission’s chief executive officer, wrote that “the NCAA has made changes over the years to improve definitions and comparability but there may continue to be differences in how institutions report the data."

"That said," she added, "these audited reports represent the most accurate athletics financial reports available and the data are used by the NCAA to produce ‘dashboard metrics’ that institutional leaders use to assess their athletic programs’ financial health. These institutional data are rarely seen by the public.”

The Knight Commission employs financial data that schools are required to submit to the NCAA that is “subject to agreed-upon procedures performed by a qualified independent accountant,” according to the commission, and approved by university presidents or chancellors.

Perko added that “the Knight Commission has always believed that – at their best – intercollegiate sports provide important educational opportunities for college athletes and benefits for the entire university community. We also believe that more effective disclosure of finances – and of financial priorities – will enhance the long-term prospects of college sports by ensuring they remain part of, not apart from, the core mission of universities.’’

Major increase in athletic spending

Whatever differences there may be between how schools do their accounting, there is no doubt Delaware has seen a huge increase in athletic expenditures and university support since Assanis and Rawak appeared in the spring of 2016.

For the 2015-16 school year, the last before they arrived, Delaware had $34.31 million in athletics funding, with $28.05 million, or 82%, coming from UD coffers.

In just two years, Delaware’s annual spending on athletics increased $10 million, all provided by the university.

“I was looking for the best person to take the athletics program here to the next level,” Assanis said when Rawak was hired. “ ... The first thing we need to be is the best within the [Colonial Athletic Association].”

Rawak, who came to Delaware from the University of Michigan, was determined to build a stronger foundation upon which championship seasons could be constructed. Assanis provided the financial resources, with the board of trustees’ support.

“If you were to look at each of the different programs and how they’ve achieved, my answer would be ‘Yes,’” Rawak said when asked if Delaware was making good on that investment. “They’re all in different places.”

BLUE HENS BACK: First group returns to use athletic facilities

In that board of trustees' committee on student life and athletics meeting, Rawak described her intentions to make Delaware a “Cinderella story” in college athletics, suggesting the Blue Hens had to rise from wretched depths to reach championship heights. It’s why her strategic plan for athletics is titled “Project Glass Slipper.”

In actuality, Delaware seems miscast for that role.

The Blue Hens have hardly been viewed by collegiate counterparts as forlorn or deserving pity despite the ups and downs of their teams, making the rags-to-riches fairy-tale comparison suspect. Delaware has often been held in high regard by sporting peers, though many would agree that its teams could fare better overall in the conference.

In the few years before Rawak came, UD women’s basketball teams, thanks to Elena Delle Donne’s presence, went to the 2012 and 2013 NCAA tournaments. Their male counterparts followed in 2014.

Men’s soccer, having not reached NCAA play since 1970, made the 2011 and 2013 NCAA brackets. Field hockey began its run of CAA titles and NCAA berths in 2013. Women’s track won the 2014 CAA title.

Before that, the football team reached national title games in 2003, 2007 and 2010, winning the first. Men’s lacrosse was in four NCAA tournaments from 2005-11, including a Final Four appearance in 2007; and volleyball made four NCAA trips from 2007-11.

But to enhance its championship chances, Delaware has spent more.

"It's allowing us to do something really special here for what I believe is a really special place and has the ability to achieve," Rawak said.

OLYMPIC STAND RESONATES: Smith's, Carlos' 1968 protest still goes unheeded

JMU, which has five fewer teams and 100 fewer athletes than Delaware, had $51.72 million in funding for 2017-18 with $41.7 million from institutional/government sources, most from mandatory fees imposed on students.

The USA Today data reveals FBS members Air Force Academy ($40.2 million) and Connecticut ($39 million) as the only others allocating more university-derived funds for athletics than Delaware.

Delaware receives 86.25% of its athletic funding from the university, ranking it ninth among the 230 Division I schools in the USA Today compilation. Among the eight ahead of Delaware was CAA rival Towson (87.17%).

Though it comes under the heading of “institutional/government support,” UD officials insist the university, not state taxpayers, provides the economic sustenance for Blue Hens sports. The Senate Joint Finance Committee approved $125 million in 2020-21 annual funding for UD on June 5.

State Rep. John Kowalko, whose 25th district includes UD's campus, doubts the contention that taxpayer dollars are not being used to support athletics.

“I’m saying, ‘Prove it,’” Kowalko said. “That money could be intermingled dramatically. … Until they agree they are willing to support the repeal of their FOIA, so I can look at these numbers, I don’t believe them.”

Kowalko was referring to the University of Delaware being exempt from state records laws, including most Freedom of Information Act requests. That means the university does not need to provide the public with details of its accounting.

“I believe that they are co-mingling taxpayer money,” Kowalko added, suggesting some operational dollars from the state likely do support athletics. “It’s the same pot of soup.”

In response to a FOIA request submitted by The News Journal seeking more data on athletic funding, UD's associate vice president and deputy general counsel, Jennifer M. Becnel-Guzzo, wrote the “athletic department is not supported with public funds. Therefore, the university has no public records responsive to your request.”

While one UD athletic official did compare Delaware’s institutional funding to those required student fees charged at JMU and many other schools, such as UConn, Rawak said that is not correct.

She said athletic funding comes from general university resources that are drawn from various reserves but that students and their families are “not paying for athletics.”

Delaware also spent $11.77 million on athletic aid for its 600-plus student-athletes in 2017-18, according to the Knight Report. That’s roughly $20,000 per student-athlete.

NEW APPROACH: COVID forces recruiting changes for Rocco

UD’s $1.4 billion endowment does not pay for athletics and is presently not a viable source, Rawak said. But endowing components of athletics as a funding mechanism is a goal, she added.

Tuition and fees have typically risen about 4% annually for UD students, increasing $600 to $14,280 for in-state undergraduates in 2019-20 and $1,400 to $35,710 for their out-of-state counterparts.

"We don't use that to fund athletics," Rawak said, adding that the university has numerous income sources beyond student payments.

Several UD faculty members not authorized to speak on behalf of the university or the athletic department, as well as those with knowledge of the subject outside the school, disputed Rawak's contention students are not helping to foot the bill for athletics, however.

David Ridpath, an Ohio University sports management professor, agrees that “athletic programs at colleges and universities have value.” He is president of the board of directors for the Drake Group, which has a mission “to defend academic integrity in higher education from the corrosive aspects of commercialized college sports.”

“But that value is often overstated and used as an excuse to spend more,” he told The News Journal, “such as when apologists claim that athletic success influences enrollment, donations, etc. when the evidence on that is mixed at best.

“So it becomes a perpetual cycle of trying to be something you are not, and chasing someone else who is likely spending money they don’t have. A school can have a successful athletic program without continuing to spend more and more where likely the end game is exactly the same as when they started.”

Changing to spur success

Part of Rawak’s efforts to improve UD athletic fortunes has included changing head coaches in 12 of Delaware’s 21 varsity sports.

The seven conference titles Delaware has won since Rawak came – three in field hockey (2016, 2017 and 2019) and one each in men’s soccer (2016), baseball (2017), women’s golf (2017) and women’s outdoor track and field (2019) – were all by teams with head coaches who were here before Rawak’s arrival.

In 2016, Delaware also won the NCAA field hockey title.

“If you were to look at the successes of our programs, collectively, all of them, one of the things to recognize is, Rome wasn’t built in a day,” said Rawak, who is frequently lauded by staff for her positive approach and leadership. “It takes time."

The 2019-20 school year was, by far, Delaware’s most successful recently from a won-loss standpoint before the shutdown.

The previous three, Blue Hen squads went 189-188-2 in 2016-17, 170-184-6 in 2017-18 and 162-200-3 last year. Along with that CAA women’s track title, the 2018-19 season did feature the return to the national rankings by the men’s lacrosse team.

The 147-99-4 record in 2019-20 was a dramatic improvement and likely reflected some new coaches reaping the benefits of their programs getting re-established.

In addition to more field hockey success, this school year featured a 22-11 record in men’s basketball, its best in six seasons; women’s soccer had its highest finish, second place, in 18 Colonial Athletic Association seasons and most wins (12) since 1994; women’s cross-country was a best-ever second in the CAA meet; men’s tennis was 14-1 with a chance at the winningest season in school history when it ended prematurely; softball was 19-4, equaling its best start ever, at the time spring sports were halted.

Other sports, however, such as football – long the university’s pride and joy – and women’s basketball, struggled to regain past glories.

LEARNING FROM LEGENDS: QBs enjoy video meetings with Blue Hen greats

After ending a seven-year NCAA football playoff absence in 2018, Delaware went 5-7 last fall, its third under coach Danny Rocco. Despite a veteran lineup, women’s basketball was 12-17 under third-year coach Natasha Adair.

Among recent athletic upgrades at Delaware have been devoting more resources toward sports such as swimming, tennis, golf, cross-country and track, which were once designated as “low-tier.” Tennis players often supplied their own rackets, and runners received just one pair of shoes for a season.

Much of Rawak’s approach has gone toward adding staff positions aimed at supporting the athletic mission, such as in heath-, media-, academic- and leadership-related positions.

In 2015-16, Delaware spent $3.65 million on support and administrative compensation, according to the Knight Commission. Two years later, that figure had nearly doubled to $6.8 million.

The UD staff directory on BlueHens.com recently listed 219 positions, including 14 involved with recreation programs and intramural activities at Carpenter Sports Building on central campus.

In contrast, several FBS schools that are close to Delaware in terms of spending list far fewer, such as Conference USA’s Old Dominion (166), Mountain West member Wyoming (186) and the MAC’s Buffalo (193).

The University of Delaware does not reveal salaries of its coaches or athletic administrators, even though some are among the First State’s highest-paid employees.

In doing so, UD cites its status as a state-assisted yet privately chartered and governed institution. Taxpayer dollars do typically account for roughly 10% of the university’s annual operating budget.

The university's IRS Form 990, which is made public, does list the highest compensated employees.

It is known that Rocco was the third-highest paid UD employee in 2017, according to the most recently available IRS Form 990, with total compensation of $609,167. Rawak ranked seventh at $480,046.

Both have taken 5% pay cuts, along with Adair and men’s basketball coach Martin Ingelsby, as part of COVID-19 money-saving measures.

Ridpath, the Ohio University professor, termed Delaware’s institutional and government support “a significant amount of money that could have been used for other things to support the educational mission, but Delaware made a choice.”

But was it the right choice?

“For Delaware, that is pretty high of an amount,” Ridpath said. “There are many disadvantages, not the least of which is aptly explained as robbing Peter to pay Paul. I don’t think some funding like this is inherently bad but this amount is too much considering where the money is coming from.

“... The real danger is schools like Delaware that don’t generate enough revenue [income] still increasing spending. The question is why and how that impacts university?”

New financial sources surface

The huge financial impact athletics has on a college is not new.

In his 1918 tome “The Higher Learning in America,” economist and sociologist Thorstein Veblen wrote: “College sports come in for ever increasing attention and take an increasingly prominent and voluminous place in the university’s life.”

He warned collegiate athletics was “earnestly pushed by the businesslike authorities” even though, he added, “it is the most widely out of touch with all learning.”

These are modern-day arguments as well, though UD athletes tend to perform better academically than their counterparts. Ten teams had perfect scores in 2018-19 in the NCAA’s Academic Progress Rate, which measures academic eligibility and retention of scholarship athletes over a four-year period.

In the introduction to his 2019 book, Intercollegiate Athletics Inc., George Mason University economics and public policy professor James T. Bennett wrote that collegiate athletic programs have become “gargantuan, taxpayer-supported spectacles that now dominate many public universities.”

Of Delaware pulling so much of its athletic revenue from institutional sources, Bennett said, “That’s not revenue at all. Revenues come from ticket sales and paraphernalia sales. This isn’t revenue.”

It’s actually a subsidy that’s granted, in this case, by the university.

“The whole thing is a scam, very candidly,” Bennett said. “I mean, what’s the purpose of the university? I thought it was education.”

“Highest-paid guy is some loser coach,” added Bennett, who was speaking generally not specifically about anyone at Delaware. “What does it say about priorities? Spending tens of million dollars on programs with zero academic value. This is unheard of throughout Europe and the rest of the world. Think of how you could divert that money.”

CENTER OF ATTENTION: Howard starter Prince transfers to Delaware

Delaware has shown the potential to tap into other monetary resources, however.

One of Delaware’s biggest victories off the field in recent years, for all to see, did come in fundraising, though there was a substantial cost to the university as well.

In a campaign separate from normal athletic support involving capital funds, UD contributed $25 million toward the $60 million project to refurbish the west grandstand of Delaware Stadium and build the adjoining Whitney Athletic Center.

The other $35 million was raised through private donations, including a $10 million gift from 1980 graduate and former UD golf team member Ken Whitney and his wife, Elizabeth. The nearly two-year project is slated to be concluded late this summer.

The easy transmission of the coronavirus between people, which has led to social-distancing standards, jeopardizes the immediate future of crowded assemblies and the financial rewards that come with them, however. Delaware has not yet announced how it will handle or limit football crowds this season.

UD has other facility improvements it would like to tackle, including updating the east stands at Delaware Stadium and a complete modernization of the window-less Delaware Field House. The Delaware Stadium/Whitney Athletic Center project demonstrated there are potential outside financial resources for athletics.

“The fundraising we did here,” Rawak said during a tour of Delaware Stadium, “was a significantly positive sign that people believe in the vision and are invested in it."

Officials also visualize Delaware Stadium as a greater potential revenue generator by using it as a site for large-scale events, much the way the Carpenter Center is a setting for concerts, graduations and other gatherings beyond UD games. Placing a temporary public ice-skating rink inside Delaware Stadium in the winter, for instance, and even playing hockey games there has been proposed.

The athletic department received just $710,000 from donor contributions in 2017-18, below the FCS median, according to the Knight Commission (Donations for the Delaware Stadium/Whitney Center project count separately because they're for a capital project not athletic expenses).

With the exception of several Historically Black Colleges and Universities, most FCS schools had a larger percentage of their revenue from those sources than Delaware.

In marked contrast, perennial FCS football champ North Dakota State pulled in $6.7 million in donor contributions; CAA rival William & Mary, $5.8 million; Missouri State, $4.7 million; football power Montana State, $4.2 million; and JMU, $2.5 million.

With schools having to rein in athletic costs because of COVID-19’s impact, Delaware faces a stiff challenge in its continued effort to improve its sports fortunes while also being fiscally fit and tuned in to important social issues.

“I don’t resent that fact that they are trying to make major sports programs prominent for this university,” Kowalko said, “but is it at the cost of academics? Is it at the cost of integrating the school when they talk about diversity?”

Have an idea for a compelling local sports story or is there an issue that needs public scrutiny? Contact Kevin Tresolini at ktresolini@delawareonline.com and follow on Twitter @kevintresolini. Support local journalism by subscribing to delawareonline.com.

search_result.text:
Margie Fishman, and Christina Jedra

The News Journal

Mike Purzycki believes that if you make it pretty, they will come.

Garbage-strewn streets suggest "your city is not well." Rusted fences and 10-foot-tall weeds penetrate residents' psyches, leading them to misbehave.

“You do what you want to do because things aren’t going to get a whole lot worse," says the man who brought an IMAX movie theater, luxury apartments, multiple corporate headquarters and even Starbucks to a 100-acre smokestack graveyard flanking a polluted river.

Soon, the Riverfront development chief could face his biggest challenge yet: persuading the broader community — and the nation — that Wilmington has outgrown its "Murder Town" label.

A former real estate developer and attorney, Purzycki's recipe is to rehabilitate the city through community redevelopment fueled by private business. But critics worry that his history of negotiating advantageous deals with a select group of developers on the Riverfront could derail success and simply make the rich richer.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

"There is almost nothing I can imagine where what's good for a developer would not be good for the city," Purzycki said recently.

After winning Wilmington's Democratic mayoral primary last month, Purzycki is relying on his record of economic growth — calling it "unmatched in Delaware" — to sail through the November general election. He faces Republican businessman Robert Martin and Independent Steve Washington — two candidates lacking high expectations for victory in a Democrat stronghold.

For two decades, Purzycki oversaw the transformation of the Christina Riverfront from an industrial wasteland to a family-friendly entertainment destination heralded by city, state and community leaders. Along the way, RDC leaders have leveraged an estimated $350 million in public funds into $1 billion in private investment, bringing more than 1,400 residents and 6,000 employees to the district, according to the corporation's statistics.

Supporters call Purzycki a courageous and transformational leader who won't back down.

"He feels a sense of urgency, which is contagious, surrounds himself with good people and doesn’t give up when he’s convinced he’s right,” said U.S. Sen. Tom Carper, D-Del., who was governor when the Riverfront Development Corp. was formed. "Without Mike at the helm, I’m not sure we’d have made it as far as we have.”

Purzycki's pro-business platform — he supports giving companies tax and regulatory incentives to spur employment — and direct pipeline to state leaders have earned him support among Delaware's power brokers in the legal and development communities. Taken together, those constituencies donated tens of thousands of dollars to the 71-year-old candidate, according to campaign finance records. Purzycki raised nearly $42,000, more than his seven rivals combined, during a recent three-week fundraising period, records show.

Purzycki is proud of that endorsement. It proves that people who made significant investments in the city trust him to deliver, he says.

Critics worry that the larger community could be shortchanged under a Purzycki administration. Over his tenure overseeing the development group, Purzycki has been blamed for not fulfilling the RDC's original mission (which also included redevelopment along the Brandywine), brokering back-room deals with real estate investors for public money, and for creating a wealthy playground on the river that doesn't encourage minority participation or benefit Wilmington's most troubled neighborhoods.

"As a businessman and making his clients and sponsors money, Mike's done well with that," said the Rev. Derrick Johnson, a Wilmington pastor who clashed with Purzycki while serving on the board of the HOPE Commission.

"But he's also separated communities," Johnson, of Joshua Harvest Church, added. "It plays into this notion that there's this classist divide between us."

Purzycki's opponents raised similar concerns during the primary. During one mayoral debate, after Purzycki questioned Eugene Young's experience, the Delaware Center for Justice Advocacy director fired back that the city is "not a corporation where you ... just turn a profit."

In another debate, City Councilwoman Maria Cabrera called the "gentrified" Riverfront an example of what has gone wrong in the city's economic development policy.

"We should have mandated they hire minorities," said Cabrera, the city's first female Hispanic council member.

The RDC, as a quasi-public agency, is not required to keep statistics on minority contractors or other employees at the Riverfront. Anecdotally, there is "plenty" of minority participation, according to Acting Executive Director Megan McGlinchey.

Purzycki acknowledges that managing a nonprofit development corporation, which sells waterfront views and receives roughly half its $6.4 million budget from the state, is a different animal than a diverse city with entrenched poverty, gun violence and a $155 million budget that never seems to stretch far enough.

"I will concede the fact that the average profile of the employee on the Riverfront is not consistent with the job market available in our neighborhoods," he said. "I get that. We've got to deal with that."

Yet he remains convinced that he can transfer the Riverfront's success to all of Wilmington by adopting a similar strategy: Use zoning tools to bar certain businesses, such as warehouses, from entering a neighborhood; knock down dilapidated buildings; lay down infrastructure; and attract private business.

"There are places in our city that aren't developing and people want them to be something — a shopping center, a park, an employment center," he said. "The trouble is you have to create an environment that the employer wants to be in, that the developer wants to develop in."

You have to improve the environment or else, frankly, they're not going to come."

'Fool's errand'

Before the trampoline park, beer garden, CrossFit, and the 212-acre wildlife refuge, there was contaminated land and little hope.

Carper recalled inviting then-Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer — father of Baltimore's revived Inner Harbor— to walk the Christina riverfront back when "you could hardly tell the river was there" because it was so ugly.

"What do you think?" the Delaware governor asked his counterpart. "Is this a fool's errand?"

Schaefer persuaded Carper to create a public-private partnership to shepherd redevelopment of the district, once a manufacturing hub for railroad cars, paper mill rollers, boilers and boats. In 1995, the Governor's Task Force established the Riverfront Development Corp. with $4.5 million in seed funding to oversee the development of the Brandywine and Christina rivers toward the goals of creating economic vitality, improving the environment, encouraging historic preservation and promoting public access.

Purzycki, a former New Castle County Councilman and state Senate attorney, joined as executive director a year later. Early on, he realized that in order to persuade developers to sign on, he had to make the riverfront appear like a prosperous place to do business.

STORY: Riverfront Development Corporation marks two decades

The Brandywine took a back seat after it became clear that the quickest path to redevelopment was targeting land on either side of the Christina River along Justison and South Market streets. In the future, the RDC may revisit bringing manufacturing jobs and recreational amenities to the Brandywine, Purzycki said.

That can't happen soon enough, according to Wilmington Councilman Darius Brown, who represents the 3rd District.

"For well over a generation, 7th Street Peninsula, 12th Street Connector, the former Electric Hose & Rubber factory site on East 12th Street and Todds Lane have been ideas, conversations and unimplemented plans," Brown wrote in a recent email. "That has to change."

Like moving pieces on a chess board, RDC leaders have experimented with different Riverfront offerings. A much-promoted exhibition center failed after a handful of blockbuster presentations. The space later became the Chase Center, which now hosts business conferences, trade shows and weddings.

Outlet retailers bailed at the Shipyard Shops, which is now an office and retail complex that is 92 percent occupied, according to the RDC.

Kahunaville, once Delaware's biggest nightclub, is now the Delaware Children’s Museum with a miniature golf course out back.

"The best projects were the ones we didn't do," Purzycki said, referring to the chain restaurants and lower-grade hotels that wanted to locate there.

STORY: Riverfront beer garden returning in '17 with upgrades

The Riverfront has had its share of setbacks, the former University of Delaware football star acknowledges. In 2002, a state-commissioned report cited weak financial management at RDC under Purzycki, blaming the corporation's $3 million cash shortfall on a failed land deal and RDC staff's lack of experience in mounting large-scale exhibitions at the First USA Riverfront Arts Center.

The report also recommended increased scrutiny on the relationship between the RDC and the private development company owned by the Pettinaro family. The Pettinaros are a major landowner on the Christina Riverfront and their company was hired to do much of the construction, including the Shipyard Shops.

Purzycki disputed many of the report's findings at the time, explaining that the study held the Riverfront agency to the same standards as a for-profit organization. More recently, he said the RDC functions like a government agency requiring long-term public subsidy like the Parks or Police departments.

The RDC, with a staff of 10, has reported an operating loss of $4 million to $13 million in each of the last dozen years, according to IRS tax forms. A $7.8 million operating loss was reported in fiscal 2015, the most recent year available. Purzycki earned more than $176,000 in salary and other compensation that year, more than Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams's current salary of $115,276.

McGlinchey, the acting RDC director, said the operating figures are skewed because they include real estate depreciation and don't account for the state's annual contribution, which has hovered around $3 million, along with revenues pumped into the local economy.

In reality, McGlinchey said, the RDC is performing break-even on operations or at a surplus. Further, most if not all the public money expended at the Riverfront to date has been repaid, largely through increased tax revenues, she said. By next year, public revenues associated with new Riverfront activity will pay for all public expenditures, including an estimated $66 million for amenity projects like Tubman-Garrett Riverfront Park that were never intended to “make money," according to a 2012 economic analysis of the Riverfront conducted by University of Delaware researchers.

Judging the RDC on numbers alone, it has been a success for state and local governments, said Jonathan Justice, a UD public policy professor.

What the RDC is not, however, is a true community development corporation — a grassroots effort focused on developing community resources, Justice said. Rather, it functions as an arm of the state without having to follow the same contracting procedures or disclosure requirements.

"It was created in a form that provides just enough distance that some of the rules apply differently," he said.

Rewarding risk-takers

The News Journal has chronicled how the RDC, over its history, has sealed deals with select developers willing to take on the risk of the Riverfront. As of 2012, the Buccini/Pollin Group had benefited from more than half of taxpayers' $250 million investment in the Riverfront, according to a previous newspaper report.

In a recent interview, BPG co-president Rob Buccini praised Purzycki's ability to look several steps ahead in assessing projects.

"We're not always in agreement, but he's usually right," Buccini said. "I have to be a lot nicer to him now."

Added Purzycki: "It's hard to imagine our city without Buccini/Pollin — building after building after building...It was money extraordinarily well spent."

STORY: Buccini/Pollin buys 3 buildings in Wilmington

Time and again, Purzycki went to bat with the state for BPG and the Riverfront.

The Penn Cinema project, built in partnership with BPG, hit a snag after Norfolk Southern Railway Co. sued the state in Delaware Superior Court, alleging that its south Madison Street property was illegally seized for the cinema. The two parties eventually settled.

In 2010, the RDC secured the property from the state Department of Transportation for $2 million — nearly $4 million less than its highest appraised value. At the time, Purzycki said that appraisal didn't take into account the recession's impact on the Riverfront real estate.

Soon after, Purzycki approached the state about giving a $6 million letter of credit for a 10-story Westin Hotel being developed by BPG principals. That prompted some lawmakers and hotel operators to complain about unfair competition.

At the time, The News Journal published emails between Purzycki and Secretary of State Jeff Bullock in which the pair discussed ways to cobble together cash from taxpayer-supported agencies to fund the hotel next to the Chase Center on the Riverfront.

In one, Purzycki asked Bullock: "If the state is a supporter of the project, do you want to keep a high or low profile?"

In the end, the city of Wilmington and RDC provided $3 million in loan guarantees for the Westin, which has since been repaid, according to RDC officials.

The Westin's current occupancy rate is 77 percent, according to the hotel's operator, beating original projections. Chase Center revenue is up 7 percent this year with nearly $5.4 million in total sales.

But the full-service hotel hasn't been the game-changer that advocates had envisioned.

"The Westin hasn't helped the Chase Center yet," Purzycki said recently. "It's only 180 rooms so if you're going to bring 500 people to town, 180 rooms isn't enough."

Earlier this year, Buccini/Pollin announced plans to build two new hotels at the Riverfront, a 200-room Marriott and a 100-room Homewood Suites. Unlike the Westin, new hotel projects won't seek public funding, Purzycki said.

STORY: Candidates discuss crime, education and parks

By the end of this year, work is expected to begin on a bridge connecting U.S. 13 with the Riverfront, opening up the south side of the river to more development.

The RDC doesn't track vacancy rates in the district, but McGlinchey estimates they're under 10 percent overall.

As the Riverfront continues to evolve, the public shouldn't lose sight of how far it has come, said Edward C. Ratledge, who has studied the fiscal impacts of the Riverfront.

To illustrate his point, the director of UD's Center for Applied Demography & Survey Research cited the state's investment in drugmaker AstraZeneca, which came to Delaware in 1999. The state gave the company more than $40 million in grants and tax credits and spent another $70 million upgrading roads in and around AstraZeneca's Fairfax campus.

Since that time, the British pharmaceutical giant has reduced Delaware jobs to about 2,100 employees as part of company-wide layoffs and is looking to relocate its operations elsewhere in Delaware.

By comparison, the RDC transformed a brownfield into a thriving mini-city.

"You can't gentrify a junkyard," Ratledge said, responding to Riverfront critics. "A lot of things are controversial down there because you don't know the outcome."

Demanding accountability

Around town, residents are already calling Purzycki "Mr. Mayor."

He has issued a slew of recommendations for how to improve Wilmington: Speed up the construction permitting process, expand blue-collar job opportunities and encourage employers to hire local and employees to live local.

STORY: What a Purzycki administration might look like

As he did at the Riverfront, he says he will emphasize staff accountability. He supports assembling neighborhood stabilization units, teams of people from multiple city departments that assume responsibility for distinct geographic areas.

A management audit is in order, according to Purzycki. Any city department that isn't functioning effectively will be considered for cuts. He declined to name specific departments.

McGlinchey is Purzycki's likely successor at the RDC and the two look forward to continued partnerships. At the same time, Purzycki has pledged to invest in struggling neighborhoods without displacing current residents and tackle recidivism as a fundamental public safety issue, as he did as board chairman of the HOPE Commission.

"I think the mayor has to be more politically sensitive than I've had to be," he said recently. "I've had to have political considerations with decisions we've made but the mayor represents everybody in every corner of the city."

Purzycki, who would be city's first white mayor in more than two decades, fiercely defends his positions, Pastor Johnson recalled. During a 2008 HOPE Commission meeting, Johnson and Purzycki got into a heated exchange over implementing a program to assign social workers to dangerous drug corners. Johnson criticized his colleagues for not dispatching the workers quickly enough. The argument escalated and Purzycki got in Johnson's face, according to a newspaper report at the time. Johnson slapped Purzycki and the two were separated; both eventually apologized.

Purzycki operates on the premise that if you fix the environment, then you'll "fix people," Johnson said recently. But that underestimates entrenched inequality.

"The wealthier folks just have more ground," he said.

Purzycki disagreed. Aligning the priorities of the business community with the larger community will increase the tax base, bring in more jobs and higher wages, he said.

"There's no zero sum there," he added. "Who's losing in that one?"

News Journal reporters Scott Goss and Jeff Mordock contributed to this report.

Contact Margie Fishman at (302) 324-2882, on Twitter @MargieTrende or mfishman@delawareonline.com. Contact Christina Jedra at (302) 324-2837, on Twitter @ChristinaJedra or cjedra@delawareonline.com.

Former NCCO political adversary supports Purzycki

Before she became a state senator, Karen Peterson served on the New Castle County Council with Mike Purzycki during the 1980s.

"We were at each other's throats in those days," the former council president recalls.

Back then, Purzycki, a real estate attorney and developer, and Peterson butted heads on issues like equal pay for women in the workplace.

"His feeling was 30 years ago that if women want to get paid the same as men they should get men's jobs," the Stanton Democrat said.

Purzycki reiterated that position in a 1985 article in Delaware Lawyer. “Like other socially desirable goals," he explained, "raising women’s wages has a cost. "Once it is removed from the ambit of intentional and invidious discrimination, it belongs with other cures for social ills that must yield to cost-benefit analysis."

Looking back, Purzycki said in a recent interview that he voted against "comparable worth" legislation not because he disagreed with the objective, but because the methodology was "deeply flawed." At the time, he felt the same aims could be achieved through collective bargaining, he said.

"As to my comments in Delaware Lawyer...I can only say looking back that while cost of compensation is a consideration it can never be a justification for discrimination," he added.

Purzycki resigned from the council in 1991 after nine years. At the time, he said his purchase of a Wilmington apartment complex could lead to the perception of favoritism or a conflict of interest.

"I believe the necessary difference between my political and professional roles is strained," he wrote in his resignation letter.

Over his tenure, Purzycki was dogged by conflict-of-interest accusations given his dual roles as a real estate investor and councilman voting on zoning decisions that affected one of his business partners. At one point, Purzycki called in the state Attorney General's Office to weigh in; investigators ruled that he had violated no laws.

But Purzycki also helped write the county ethics code, criticized his political opponents for their cozy relationships with developers, intervened on constituents' behalf to block two office projects, and encouraged the county to wean itself off state and federal support and focus on local efficiencies.

He had a running feud with Edward "Pete" Peterson, former president of the state AFL-CIO and Peterson's daughter, Karen.

But time has healed political wounds. Purzycki is "honest" and "ethical" and his business connections are a "real advantage," Karen Peterson said recently, adding that Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams does not enjoy the same rapport with business executivies.

Further, Purzycki's experience at the HOPE Commission means he's attuned to the consequences of warehousing criminals, Peterson said.

"My greatest fear is seeing Wilmington becoming Chester, Pa.," the Chester native added. "That's the direction we're heading. I think that Mike is the one person who can put the brakes on that and turn it around."

search_result.title: University of Delaware plans $60M upgrade to stadium, athlete center
search_result.text:
Delaware Stadium, which has beckoned Blue Hens football fans for decades despite its fading beauty, is about to receive a long-awaited major makeover.

The University of Delaware announced at halftime of Saturday’s 22-3 football win over Albany that the 22,000-seat Newark facility will undergo a $60 million transformation.

It will include installing chair-back seating in the three middle sections – C, D and E – of the west (home side) grandstand and box-seat area just above Tubby Raymond Field.

More noticeably, it includes construction of a five-story, 90,000-square-foot, glass-and-steel building that will run the length of the stadium outside the west grandstand.

SATURDAY'S GAME:Delaware can't afford slip-up in home football finale

Its upper floors will rise above the stadium, providing modern media and game-day coaching boxes on the top level and a large enclosed gathering area with 400 club seats and two suites one level below.

The bottom floors will have areas to serve Delaware’s 600-plus varsity athletes.

“The athletic center and the renovation of the west side is a game changer for us from an athletics perspective,” Delaware Athletic Director Chrissi Rawak said, “in our ability to be competitive with recruiting but also provide our student-athletes with exceptional experiences.”

Echoing Delaware fans, Rawak termed the stadium renovations “long overdue.”

The first floor will house health and wellness areas, including athletic training, sports medicine, nutrition, sports psychology and strength and conditioning, including a new weight room.

The second floor will be devoted to “student success,” said Rawak, referring to academic support, leadership development, career preparation and multi-purpose space.

The west stands will be razed and rebuilt, Rawak said.

The university is kicking in $25 million of that $60 million cost, it was announced at Saturday's home football game. Rawak termed the university’s financial support “truly remarkable. I am, and I know our coaches and team members are, very grateful.”

It was also revealed Delaware has already raised $23 million of the remaining $35 million from private donors. Many of the private donors were on the field at halftime during Saturday's announcement, which included fireworks and a video presentation.

"For us who have been part of this tradition for so many decades, we always wanted to construct a monument that was commensurate with the tradition that was already built," said Joe Purzycki, the 1969 UD football captain standing beside brother Mike, the Wilmington mayor who played for Delaware from 1964-66.

"For years we've been dragging our feet," added Joe Purzycki, excited that construction of such a facility will now take place.

"It'll give the program a real shot in the arm," Mike Purzycki said.

The stadium upgrade and athletic performance center construction are part of UD’s new fundraising campaign, branded “Delaware First,” which has an overall goal of $750 million.

BACKGROUND:$750 million needed to bring the UD to 'the next level'

Among the outside donors are Delaware Board of Trustees member Kenneth C. Whitney and his wife, Liz Whitney, who were not present Saturday. They have made what UD termed "a transformational lead gift" of $10 million that will go toward the athletic performance center. It will bear the Whitney name, Rawak said.

Ken Whitney played golf at Delaware from 1977 to 1979 and graduated in 1980 with an accounting degree. He has been a longtime employee at the Blackstone Group, an asset management company, in New York City and is also a Tony Award-winning producer.

In 2005, they established the Whitney Family Scholarship Endowment. They then created the Whitney Family Endowed Chair in UD's Lerner College of Business and Economics in 2011.

“Athletics is an integral part of creating an extraordinary experience for our students, our alumni and our community. Our student-athletes and fans deserve top-notch facilities,” UD President Dennis Assanis said. “Through the Delaware First campaign, we are committed to strengthening the athletics program to [the] Blue Hen nation now and for generations to come.”

Construction will not begin until Delaware has raised all the money, which they hope to conclude by the end of the 2018 football season.

The plan is to have the grandstand seating plus the upper sections of the building, containing the club suites and seating and press box area, done by the 2019 football season. The first home game that year is Sept. 7 against Delaware State.

The rest of the athletic performance center project would be concluded in time for the 2020 season.

“After all the false starts, it’s just fantastic to see this finally come to fruition,” said Middletown resident Harold Smith, a 1964 UD grad and baseball player who has been regularly attending football games since 1966. “It’s so needed by all of our athletes, not just football. It’s just going to be wonderful to see them have the facilities they need to be better students and better athletes.

“The improvements of the stands will benefit the fans and make us more proud of our stadium and bring it up to more modern standards. As far as amenities for the media, which people may not think that’s important, what we have now is an embarrassment to our university.”

Ryan Allen, a freshman guard on the men’s basketball team who would be a senior in the fall of 2020, said it’s “very exciting” to know a facility such as the athletic performance center is coming.

“It’s a great sign for the recruits, too,” he said. “We’ll be able to get a lot of things done in there.”

Coaches have already used the future facility in recruiting, where it is “extraordinarily significant,” football coach Danny Rocco said.

“The landscape is changing so dramatically across the country,” Rocco added. “All these schools are trying to do things to remain as relevant as they can in the recruiting market. It will offer a definite spike across the board for Delaware athletics.”

John Dollmeyer, president of the Blue Hen Touchdown Club fan support group, said the commitment of the UD Board of Trustees and Assanis to Blue Hen athletes was particularly noteworthy.

“It’s gonna put us in the upper echelon of the CAA [Colonial Athletic Association] and be a real boost for the university,” Dollmeyer said.

HNTB Architecture Inc., a design and construction management firm that has worked on many professional and NCAA Division I football stadiums, has done the renderings. Delaware now has a request for proposal out allowing companies to bid on the design phase of the project.

The changes will slightly lower stadium capacity because the newer chair-back seats will be wider. But Delaware hasn’t averaged more than 20,000 fans per home game since 2010.

Delaware Stadium is also the home of the university’s men’s and women’s lacrosse teams. Aside from Blue Hens football and lacrosse games, UD’s annual commencement ceremony, the annual DFRC Blue-Gold all-star high school football game in June and a few other college and high school football games, the stadium is rarely used for big events.

Rawak hopes to change that.

“This is an athletic asset, but it really is a community asset, a university asset and a state asset that brings people together,” she said, mentioning concerts as one possible draw. “We’re envisioning so much more being able to be accomplished and people gathering in ways they are not now.”

Delaware, because of its large football following and – until recently – winning tradition, has also long been viewed as a candidate for a move to the highest level of NCAA competition – the Division I Football Bowl Subdivision. Delaware presently resides in the Division I Football Championship Subdivision, which has a national championship playoff, won by Delaware in 2003. Delaware has won six national championships in football dating back to 1946.

Rawak said the project should not be viewed as a signal of such a move.

“There is aspiration in everything that we’re working to do here,” Rawak said. “But at the end of the day, what we need to do is be competing where we are and working toward winning national championships at the FCS level. That’s not a bad thing.”

Rawak added that the upgraded facility “gives us the opportunity to have choices. And during that period of time, I think the landscape of college athletics, as we’re seeing things take place, is going to adjust. How exactly? I’m not 100 percent sure. We can’t project that future. Are we paying attention? Absolutely we’re paying attention.”

Future stadium improvements are planned in the east stands and end zones, though Rawak would not offer specifics or a timetable.

“None of that matters unless we accomplish this,” she said.

She added that the neighboring Delaware Field House, which “needs to be gutted,” is also in need of a major overhaul apart from its artificial turf indoor practical field installed several years ago.

Contact Kevin Tresolini at ktresolini@delawareonline.com. Follow on Twitter @kevintresolini.

search_result.title: University of Delaware football stadium renovations to get under way
search_result.text:
One year after the University of Delaware announced a planned $60 million facelift for Delaware Stadium, the project is set to move forward.

Delaware announced at halftime of Saturday’s final regular-season football game against Villanova that construction work will soon commence.

“We’re gonna dig dirt after the football season is over,” UD athletic director Chrissi Rawak told The News Journal.

The Blue Hens may have another home game next week, as the NCAA Division I Football Championship Subdivision (FCS) Tournament field will be announced Sunday at 12:30 p.m. on ESPNU. First-round games are Nov. 24.

The university had announced in November 2017 it would renovate the West (home-side) stands at Delaware Stadium with improved seating, provide luxury options and build a modern structure for media and coaches’ booths.

Just outside the stadium on the west side and connected to it would be a 90,000-square-foot structure housing a wellness center, athletic training, sports medicine, nutrition, sports psychology and strength and conditioning facilities to serve UD student-athletes.

It was christened the Whitney Athletic Center after a $10 million gift from 1980 graduate and former UD golf team member Ken Whitney and his wife, Elizabeth.

“The Whitney Athletic Center will play an essential role in helping ensure the success of our student-athletes, both in competition and in the classroom,” UD president Dennis Assanis said in a university press release. “Ken and Liz Whitney have demonstrated their deep commitment to our students through their generous gift, and we appreciate everyone who has followed their lead in supporting this project.”

Of that $60 million, the university was providing $25 million, with athletics raising the other $35 million with an eye on beginning work after the 2017 football season. The “Build Our Home” athletic project is part of UD’s Delaware First fund-raising campaign launched in 2017.

Rawak said Delaware has raised $32 million, which is enough to start the work, and is certain it’ll have the rest by its June 2018 deadline.

“We have many people who have made verbal commitments and we’re just working to get those things finalized and formalized,” Rawak said. “We’re very grateful to the board [of trustees] and the president for granting us the opportunity to move forward and put shovels in the ground.”

DELAWARE STADIUM

Reviewing the best games seen fromoutgoing press box

Skeptics wondered if renovations would ever happen

Delaware announces long-awaited stadium improvements

The cost hasn’t changed in the past year, she said.

Jake Giusti, a defensive back on Delaware's 2010-14 teams, was among those honored at halftime for having contributed to the project.

"It was the greatest four-and-a-half years of my life," said Giusti, a Florida native who is now a medical-device salesman in New York City for Stryker. "With the opportunity Delaware gave me to get a football scholarship and play four-and-a-half seasons, it was the least I could do to help them get back. It's a great university and a great athletic program and Chrissi has a great vision. It was my way of saying thank you."

Construction is being done by Barton Malow, a Michigan-based company that was involved in Rose Bowl and Michigan Stadium renovations, and Wilmington’s EDiS, which took part in the original building of Delaware Stadium when it opened in 1952.

The architect is HOK Sports, whose recent stadium renovations include Georgia’s Sanford Stadium.

While the seating work will be done by next season’s Aug. 29 football opener at Delaware Stadium against Delaware State, the press box will be usable but not complete and amenities for those in club seating will also not be finished, Rawak said.

The Whitney Athletic Center is not expected to be completed until June 2020.

The club-seating area in the stadium is a major change from plans released last year by Delaware. Initial renderings had club seating at the top of the west stands and then connected to the lower floor of what would be a two-story press box, where there would be gathering areas.

Now, club seating will comprise the eight first rows of the stadium closest to the field from end-to-end on the refurbished west side and comprise roughly 1,100 seats.

“That’s based on feedback we received from our fans,” Rawak said. “They like being low. They want to be able to be close to the field. It was very clear from the feedback so that was an adjustment we made.”

Club-seat holders will have access to a room that will be constructed behind the stands and connected to the second floor of the Whitney Center, with an entrance through the bottom of Section B. It will not offer a view of the football field but will have TV monitors and other amenities, including a bar. That area will not be completed before next season.

The structure at the top of the stadium with media facilities and coaches’ booths will now be just one level.

Delaware Stadium has long been highly regarded for its viewing angles because of the steepness of its stands, and that will not change, Rawak said, as the concrete base of the grandstand will remain intact. Even the first row of those club seats will be high off the field, as the box seats there now are.

“I’m really pleased we didn’t have to tear down. That was a big win for us,” Rawak said of the economic savings and also being able to maintain the stadium’s treasured sight lines.

Sideline hedges behind the Delaware bench will have to be removed, however.

The other major change is that sections C, D and E – the middle part of the west stands – will have chairback seats from top to bottom. The entire stadium is presently bleacher seating.

Stadium capacity, which is presently about 22,000, will decrease slightly because chairback seats take up more space.

Delaware Stadium will still be able to hold its normal events, such as Delaware lacrosse games in the spring, UD commencement in May and the DFRC Blue-Gold Delaware High School All-Star Football Game in June. Seating options may be limited, however, which could be a problem for commencement, the only event that fills the stadium.

Delaware plans to release more specific football seating information to previous and potential ticket buyers in January. There will be a price increase for the higher-quality chairback seats.

Ground-level improvements will also include modernized concessions and bathrooms. In one ode to tradition, Rawak said, the popular “pee wall” will be retained in some form because of strong public opinion. That particular men’s bathroom is located at the southwest corner features large troughs in which men urinate while water runs into it from pipes above.

Improving the press box and coaching booths and providing improved seating options have been considered a Delaware Stadium need since the 1980s. The stadium didn’t even have handrails on its steep stairways until several years ago.

Over the years, various plans were hatched to modernize Delaware Stadium, some with fancy renderings. A 2008 HOK Sports plan featured a costly redesigned UD athletic complex reflecting the central green layout of main campus.

At last, improvements are imminent.

Future plans call for fixing up the East side of Delaware Stadium and major improvements to the Delaware Field House.

“I just really want everyone to feel incredible pride in this,” Rawak said of the stadium improvements and Whitney Athletic Center addition. “It’s a game changer.”
